title: Psalms Chapter 58 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Psalms chapter 58 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Psalms Chapter 58 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Psalms Chapter 58.

questions.question: According to Psalms 58:1, who is being questioned about speaking righteousness?
questions.explanation: Psalms 58:1 asks, 'Do ye indeed speak righteousness, O congregation?'

questions.question: What kind of wickedness do the sons of men work according to Psalms 58:2?
questions.explanation: Psalms 58:2 states that in heart they work wickedness.

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 58:3 says that the wicked begin speaking lies only after they are grown.
questions.explanation: Psalms 58:3 says the wicked go astray as soon as they are born, speaking lies.

questions.question: Psalms 58:4 compares the wicked's poison to what?
questions.explanation: The verse directly compares their poison to that of a serpent.

questions.question: According to Psalms 58:5, what will the deaf adder not hearken to?
questions.explanation: Psalms 58:5 states the deaf adder will not listen to the voice of charmers.

questions.question: Fill in the blank from Psalms 58:6: 'Break their ______, O God, in their mouth.'
questions.explanation: The verse says, 'Break their teeth, O God, in their mouth.'

questions.question: What does Psalms 58:7 say should happen to the wicked when he bends his bow to shoot arrows?
options: Let them be cut in pieces
questions.correctAnswer: Let them be cut in pieces
questions.explanation: The verse says the wicked should be as cut in pieces when arrows are shot.

questions.question: According to Psalms 58:8, the wicked should pass away like what?
questions.explanation: The verse uses the simile of a melting snail for the wicked passing away.

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 58:9 describes God taking the wicked away as with a whirlwind.
questions.explanation: The verse explicitly says God will take them away as with a whirlwind.

questions.question: Who shall rejoice when he seeth the vengeance, according to Psalms 58:10?
questions.explanation: Psalms 58:10 states that the righteous shall rejoice at vengeance.

questions.question: What will the righteous do with their feet in Psalms 58:10?
options: Wash them in the blood of the wicked
questions.correctAnswer: Wash them in the blood of the wicked
questions.explanation: The verse says the righteous shall wash their feet in the blood of the wicked.

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 58:11 states that there is no reward for the righteous.
questions.explanation: Psalms 58:11 affirms there is a reward for the righteous.

questions.question: According to Psalms 58:11, what kind of God is He?
options: A God that judgeth in the earth
A God that forgiveth sins only
A God that dwells in heaven alone
A God that loves only the meek
questions.correctAnswer: A God that judgeth in the earth
questions.explanation: The verse describes God as one who judges in the earth.

questions.question: What kind of lions are mentioned in Psalms 58:6?
questions.explanation: The verse refers to the great teeth of the young lions.

questions.question: Complete the phrase from Psalms 58:8: 'Like the untimely birth of a woman, that they may not see the ______.'
questions.explanation: The verse says 'that they may not see the sun.'

medium.title: Psalms Chapter 58 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Psalms Chapter 58 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is struggling with bitterness towards those who do wrong. Based on Psalms 58, what biblical truth would you share about God's judgment?
options: God will break the power of the wicked and bring justice
We should take vengeance into our own hands
God ignores the wicked and their deeds
The wicked will always prosper without consequence
questions.correctAnswer: God will break the power of the wicked and bring justice
questions.explanation: Psalms 58:6-7 emphasizes that God will break the teeth of the wicked and cut them in pieces, showing His active judgment on evil. This teaches believers to trust God's righteous justice rather than seek personal revenge.

questions.question: How does Psalms 58 teach us about integrity in daily life when it says, "Do ye indeed speak righteousness, O congregation? do ye judge uprightly, O ye sons of men?"?
options: We must speak and judge with righteousness and uprightness
It is acceptable to be biased if it benefits us
Judgment is only for the priests and not for the congregation
Righteous speech is less important than actions
questions.correctAnswer: We must speak and judge with righteousness and uprightness
questions.explanation: Psalms 58:1 calls for righteous speech and upright judgment, highlighting the importance of honesty and integrity in how we evaluate and interact with others in the community.

questions.question: A believer is tempted to lie to gain advantage at work. What warning from Psalms 58 would help them resist this temptation?
options: The wicked speak lies from birth and are estranged from righteousness
Lying is acceptable if it protects you
God overlooks small lies in daily life
Only theft is condemned, not lying
questions.correctAnswer: The wicked speak lies from birth and are estranged from righteousness
questions.explanation: Psalms 58:3 states that the wicked go astray from birth, speaking lies, which warns believers that dishonesty separates them from God and righteousness.

questions.question: How does Psalms 58 encourage believers to persevere through trials caused by wicked people?
options: Trust that God will bring vengeance and justice in His time
Ignore wrongdoing and pretend it doesn’t affect you
Seek revenge quickly before God acts
questions.correctAnswer: Trust that God will bring vengeance and justice in His time
questions.explanation: Psalms 58:10-11 affirms that the righteous will rejoice when they see God's vengeance, encouraging believers to rely on God's perfect judgment rather than personal retaliation.

questions.question: What practical lesson about humility can we learn from the description of the wicked in Psalms 58?
options: The wicked are like deaf adders refusing to listen, showing pride
Ignoring wise counsel is a sign of humility
questions.correctAnswer: The wicked are like deaf adders refusing to listen, showing pride
questions.explanation: Psalms 58:4-5 describes the wicked as deaf adders who refuse to hear wise charmers, illustrating that pride blinds people to correction and counsel, which humility seeks.

questions.question: A church leader is facing dishonesty among members. Based on Psalms 58, what biblical principle about church discipline and justice would you emphasize?
options: God judges the earth and rewards the righteous, so justice must be pursued
Discipline is unnecessary because God ignores sin
Forgiveness means overlooking wrongdoing without repentance
Leaders should avoid judging members to keep peace
questions.correctAnswer: God judges the earth and rewards the righteous, so justice must be pursued
questions.explanation: Psalms 58:11 states that God judges on earth and rewards the righteous, supporting the need for church discipline that reflects God's justice and righteousness.

questions.question: How does Psalms 58 illustrate the importance of prayer for God's intervention in dealing with evil?
options: It directly asks God to break the teeth of the wicked
It encourages people to take revenge themselves
It says prayer is ineffective against evil
questions.correctAnswer: It directly asks God to break the teeth of the wicked
questions.explanation: Psalms 58:6 is a prayer asking God to break the teeth of the wicked, illustrating reliance on divine power to overcome evil rather than human effort alone.

questions.question: True or False: According to Psalms 58, the wicked are like snails that melt away and disappear quickly.
questions.explanation: Psalms 58:8 compares the wicked to a snail which melts away, indicating their ultimate frailty and destruction under God's judgment.

questions.question: What does Psalms 58 teach about the consequences of working wickedness in the heart?
options: Violence and wickedness weigh heavily on the earth and bring judgment
Wickedness in the heart is hidden and harmless
It will always lead to prosperity
It is excused if done secretly
questions.correctAnswer: Violence and wickedness weigh heavily on the earth and bring judgment
questions.explanation: Psalms 58:2 says that wickedness works in the heart and weighs violence on the earth, showing that sin has real consequences and will be judged by God.

questions.question: How does Psalms 58 encourage believers to respond to the apparent success of the wicked?
options: To rejoice in God’s eventual vengeance and justice
To envy and seek to imitate their ways
questions.correctAnswer: To rejoice in God’s eventual vengeance and justice
questions.explanation: Psalms 58:10 encourages the righteous to rejoice when they see God's vengeance, reminding believers that God will ultimately right wrongs.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Psalm 58 compares the wicked to a serpent whose poison is like the poison of a ________.
questions.explanation: Psalms 58:4 states that the wicked's poison is like the poison of a serpent, symbolizing their harmful and deadly nature.

questions.question: True or False: According to Psalms 58, the wicked will enjoy lasting success and escape God's wrath.
questions.explanation: Psalms 58:7-9 describe how the wicked will melt away like water and be taken away in God's wrath, showing they will not escape judgment.

questions.question: A parent wants to teach their child about honesty and righteousness. Based on Psalms 58, what truth would reinforce this teaching?
options: Righteousness is rewarded by God who judges the earth
Lying is acceptable if it benefits you
Righteousness is only important for religious leaders
God prefers silence over righteous speech
questions.correctAnswer: Righteousness is rewarded by God who judges the earth
questions.explanation: Psalms 58:11 confirms that God judges the earth and rewards the righteous, encouraging teaching children to value honesty and uprightness.

questions.question: How does Psalms 58 describe the wicked's attitude towards wise counsel and correction?
options: They refuse to listen, like a deaf adder
They eagerly accept and learn from it
They pretend to listen but do not change
questions.correctAnswer: They refuse to listen, like a deaf adder
questions.explanation: Psalms 58:4-5 depicts the wicked as deaf adders who stop their ears and do not heed wise charmers, illustrating stubbornness and rejection of correction.

questions.question: What does Psalms 58 imply about God's control over the fate of the wicked?
options: God controls their downfall like a bow shooting arrows
The wicked control their own destiny without interference
God is indifferent to the wicked's fate
The wicked escape judgment through power
questions.correctAnswer: God controls their downfall like a bow shooting arrows
questions.explanation: Psalms 58:7 uses the metaphor of God bending his bow to shoot arrows to describe how He controls the destruction of the wicked.

hard.title: Psalms Chapter 58 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Psalms Chapter 58.

questions.question: What is the primary accusation against the congregation in Psalms 58:1?
questions.explanation: Psalms 58:1 questions whether the congregation truly judges uprightly, implying they do not.

questions.question: According to Psalms 58:3, from what state are the wicked estranged?
questions.explanation: Psalms 58:3 states that the wicked are estranged from the womb, indicating their sinful nature from birth.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: The wicked are compared to _______ in Psalms 58:4.
questions.explanation: Psalms 58:4 compares the wicked's poison to that of a serpent, highlighting their harmful nature.

questions.question: Which animal is used in Psalms 58:4 as a metaphor for those who refuse to listen?
questions.explanation: Psalms 58:4 uses the deaf adder that stops her ear as a metaphor for stubbornness and refusal to heed warnings.

questions.question: True or False: According to Psalms 58:5, charmers can successfully persuade the wicked.
questions.explanation: Psalms 58:5 states that the deaf adder will not hearken to charmers, meaning they cannot be persuaded.

questions.question: What is the prayer request in Psalms 58:6 regarding the wicked?
questions.explanation: Psalms 58:6 petitions God to break the teeth of the wicked, symbolizing their power to harm being removed.

questions.question: In Psalms 58:7, the wicked are likened to waters that do what?
questions.explanation: Psalms 58:7 compares the wicked to waters that run continually, suggesting they will dissolve or fade away.

questions.question: Which simile in Psalms 58:8 describes the fate of the wicked as passing away?
questions.explanation: Psalms 58:8 uses the image of a snail melting away to illustrate the swift demise of the wicked.

questions.question: What does Psalms 58:8 say about the wicked’s ability to see the sun?
options: They will not see the sun
They will shine like the sun
They will hide from the sun
questions.correctAnswer: They will not see the sun
questions.explanation: Psalms 58:8 states the wicked will be like an untimely birth that does not see the sun, indicating premature destruction.

questions.question: According to Psalms 58:9, what will take away the wicked before your pots can feel the thorns?
questions.explanation: Psalms 58:9 describes the wicked being taken away as with a whirlwind, symbolizing swift divine judgment.

questions.question: The phrase 'wash his feet in the blood of the wicked' in Psalms 58:10 is an example of what literary device?
questions.explanation: Psalms 58:10 uses metaphorical language to describe the triumph of the righteous over the wicked.

questions.question: What emotion will the righteous experience upon seeing the vengeance, according to Psalms 58:10?
questions.explanation: Psalms 58:10 states the righteous shall rejoice when they see the vengeance executed against the wicked.

questions.question: Which phrase in Psalms 58:11 affirms God's role as a judge on earth?
options: He is a God that judgeth in the earth
The earth is full of his glory
questions.correctAnswer: He is a God that judgeth in the earth
questions.explanation: Psalms 58:11 explicitly declares God's role as the righteous judge on earth.

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 58 portrays the wicked as inherently deceptive from birth.
questions.explanation: Psalms 58:3 states the wicked go astray as soon as they are born, speaking lies, indicating inherent deception.

questions.question: The literary structure of Psalms 58 employs which of the following to emphasize the fate of the wicked?
questions.explanation: Psalms 58 uses parallelism in contrasting the wicked and the righteous and metaphorical language like 'teeth' and 'snail' to emphasize the wicked's fate.

theological.title: Psalms Chapter 58 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Psalms Chapter 58 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: According to Psalms 58:3, what condition characterizes the wicked from birth?
options: They are estranged and go astray speaking lies
questions.correctAnswer: They are estranged and go astray speaking lies
questions.explanation: Psalms 58:3 states that the wicked are estranged from the womb and go astray as soon as they are born, speaking lies. This highlights the doctrine of original sin and the innate sinful nature of humanity (Genesis 8:21; Romans 3:10-12; Psalm 51:5; Jeremiah 17:9).

questions.question: What metaphor is used in Psalms 58:4 to describe the wicked's harmful nature?
questions.explanation: Psalms 58:4 compares the wicked's poison to that of a serpent, emphasizing their destructive and deceitful nature. This aligns with biblical imagery of evil as venomous and deadly (Genesis 3:14; Matthew 23:33; Romans 3:13; Proverbs 23:32).

questions.question: In Psalms 58:6, what does the psalmist ask God to do to the wicked?
options: Break their teeth in their mouth
questions.correctAnswer: Break their teeth in their mouth
questions.explanation: The psalmist petitions God to break the teeth of the wicked, symbolizing the removal of their power to harm (Psalms 58:6). This reflects God's justice and judgment against evil (Proverbs 6:16-19; Romans 12:19; Nahum 1:2; Revelation 19:11).

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Psalms 58:10 says, 'The righteous shall rejoice when he seeth the ________.'
questions.explanation: Psalms 58:10 states that the righteous rejoice when they see God's vengeance, highlighting God's role as a just judge who protects the innocent (Romans 12:19; Hebrews 10:30; Isaiah 61:2; Revelation 6:10).

questions.question: What does Psalms 58:1 question about the congregation and sons of men?
options: Do they indeed speak righteousness and judge uprightly?
questions.correctAnswer: Do they indeed speak righteousness and judge uprightly?
questions.explanation: Psalms 58:1 challenges the congregation and sons of men about their justice and righteousness, emphasizing the biblical demand for true justice (Micah 6:8; Proverbs 21:3; Isaiah 1:17; James 2:1-4).

questions.question: According to Psalms 58:2, what is said about the hearts of those being judged?
options: They work wickedness in their hearts
questions.correctAnswer: They work wickedness in their hearts
questions.explanation: Psalms 58:2 reveals that wickedness is rooted in the heart, highlighting human depravity (Jeremiah 17:9; Mark 7:21-23; Romans 3:23; Genesis 6:5). This underscores the biblical teaching that sin originates from the human heart.

questions.question: How does Psalms 58:5 describe the wicked’s response to charmers or enchantments?
options: They will not hearken to the voice of charmers
They are easily deceived by charmers
questions.correctAnswer: They will not hearken to the voice of charmers
questions.explanation: Psalms 58:5 depicts the wicked as deaf to charmers' voices, symbolizing their stubborn resistance to correction and truth (Proverbs 1:23; Hebrews 3:7-8; Isaiah 6:9-10; John 12:40).

questions.question: What does Psalms 58:7 use as a simile to describe the fate of the wicked?
options: Let them melt away as waters which run continually
Let them be as a mighty mountain
Let them stand firm like an oak tree
questions.correctAnswer: Let them melt away as waters which run continually
questions.explanation: Psalms 58:7 likens the wicked fading away to waters that continuously run, symbolizing their transient and powerless state before God's judgment (Isaiah 57:20; Job 14:14; James 4:14; Psalm 102:3).

questions.question: In Psalms 58:8, the wicked are compared to what to describe their sudden and complete destruction?
options: An untimely birth of a woman
questions.correctAnswer: An untimely birth of a woman
questions.explanation: Psalms 58:8 compares the wicked’s demise to the untimely birth of a woman, emphasizing suddenness and the absence of hope or fulfillment (Jeremiah 20:14; Job 3:16; Hosea 13:16; Nahum 1:9).

questions.question: What imagery does Psalms 58:9 use to describe God's swift judgment on the wicked?
options: He shall take them away as with a whirlwind
He shall build a wall around them
He shall cover them with a shadow
questions.correctAnswer: He shall take them away as with a whirlwind
questions.explanation: Psalms 58:9 uses the imagery of a whirlwind to depict God's swift and powerful judgment, reflecting His sovereignty and wrath (Nahum 1:3; Isaiah 66:15; Ezekiel 1:4; Revelation 6:14).

questions.question: According to Psalms 58:11, what affirmation is made about God?
options: He is a God that judgeth in the earth
He ignores the deeds of men
questions.correctAnswer: He is a God that judgeth in the earth
questions.explanation: Psalms 58:11 affirms that God judges the earth, underscoring His role as the ultimate righteous judge (Ecclesiastes 12:14; Romans 2:5-6; Psalm 96:13; 2 Corinthians 5:10).

questions.question: What does Psalms 58:10 say the righteous will do upon seeing God's vengeance?
options: Rejoice and wash their feet in the blood of the wicked
questions.correctAnswer: Rejoice and wash their feet in the blood of the wicked
questions.explanation: Psalms 58:10 describes the righteous rejoicing and symbolically washing their feet in the blood of the wicked, illustrating God's vindication of justice (Revelation 19:11-13; Isaiah 63:3; Romans 12:19; Hebrews 10:30).

questions.question: What does Psalms 58:1 imply is necessary for righteous judgment among men?
questions.explanation: Psalms 58:1 calls for righteousness and upright judgment, reflecting God's standard for human justice (Deuteronomy 16:18-20; Proverbs 21:15; Isaiah 1:17; James 2:1-4).

questions.question: How does Psalms 58:2 describe the actions of the wicked in relation to their hands?
options: They weigh the violence of their hands in the earth
They bless others with their hands
questions.correctAnswer: They weigh the violence of their hands in the earth
questions.explanation: Psalms 58:2 states that the wicked measure out violent deeds with their hands, revealing active participation in sin (Ecclesiastes 3:3; Jeremiah 22:3; Isaiah 59:6; Matthew 26:52).

questions.question: What does the psalmist request God to do with the 'great teeth of the young lions' in Psalms 58:6?
questions.explanation: Psalms 58:6 asks God to break the great teeth of young lions, symbolizing the power of the wicked to harm and the desire for God to disarm their destructive capacity (Job 4:10; Proverbs 28:15; Nahum 2:11; Isaiah 11:6).
